docs.title: Welcome to Edit Masters
docs.text:
Edit Masters is your academic learning space — a curated resource hub for developing editing, writing, and research communication skills.

Whether you're a student, researcher, or editor, this platform provides structured, day-by-day lessons designed to improve your clarity, coherence, and confidence in academic writing.

docs.title: About Us
docs.text:
At Edit Masters, we believe that effective writing is a skill that can be learned through practice and precision. Our mission is to provide reliable, practical, and well-structured materials to guide your academic journey.

📚 Start Learning - Beginners Lessons - Intermediate Lessons

docs.title: Assignment 1
docs.text:
Let's try an edit assignment! Pick a sample edit for the field you are associated with, edit it, and email it to your PoC.

Before you start editing the file, please turn on Track Changes.

docs.title: Common Errors: Sentence Structure - Assignments
docs.text:
An editor is an expert when it comes to analyzing and restructuring modifiers and complements in a sentence. To develop these skill, please do these assignments. You can use a notebook or MS Word to write your answers down. There are no right or wrong answers. Just practice. Please refer to AN ADVANCED ENGLISH GRAMMAR for reference.

2.1.1. Point out the adjectives used as modifiers of the subject. Substitute for each an adjective phrase; an adjective clause.

  1. Standing in the door was a tearful child.

  2. A tall Scot shut off my view.

  3. An iron mask concealed the prisoner’s face.

  4. Honorable men pay their debts.

  5. A tumble-down shed stood in the hollow.

  6. A three-cornered hat was cocked over one of his ears.

  7. The American Indians are becoming extinct.

  8. An experienced stenographer should spell correctly.

  9. A deep fosse or ditch was drawn round the whole building.

  10. The royal army was assembled at Salisbury.

  11. The mid-day meal was excellent.

  12. The morning mist lies heavy upon yonder chain of islands.

2.1.2. Construct sentences, using the following adjective phrases as modifiers of the subject and of the predicate:

of great height; in a red hat; with black hair; from Cairo; to Indianapolis; from India; with high gables; of brilliant plumage; on the rear platform; in a state of intense agitation; between the two ships; over the mountain; on the summit of the tower.

2.1.3 Point out all the adverbs used to modify the simple predicate. Substitute for each an adverbial phrase or clause.

  1. The witness chose his words deliberately.

  2. The old man moved slowly down the street.

  3. I carefully avoided making that promise.

  4. Do not speak so loud.

  5. I am eagerly looking forward to your visit.

  6. That golf ball must have hit him hard.

  7. Allan has played in public twice.

  8. I shall call you early.

  9. We often see your eccentric friend.

  10. The priest shook his head doubtfully.

  11. Your father barely escaped drowning.

  12. The next morning Chester awoke late.

  13. The accident happened here.

  14. The captain had gone below.

  15. Marion refuses to go by coach unless she can sit outside.

  16. Frank left home three years ago, and has not been heard from since.

  17. Look yonder and tell us where the path lies.

  18. We were then presented to Governor Gore.

  19. I have not been there since April.

  20. Bruce was afterward ashamed of his discouragement.

  21. The sun will soon set.

  22. You are expected to arrive in good season hereafter.

  23. Alice cannot spell correctly.

  24. The Indian suddenly disappeared.

  25. The girl laughed carelessly.

  26. The moose fell heavily to the earth.

  27. He passionately longs to see Italy.

  28. All foreigners seem to speak rapidly.

  29. Edith listened attentively.

docs.title: 🎓 Course Introduction and Pre-Test
docs.text: Welcome to the Beginners Lessons! This course will help you strengthen fundamental aspects of English grammar and vocabulary before moving on to more advanced areas of editing, such as comprehension and technical accuracy.

docs.title: 🧭 Let’s Begin
docs.text:
Before you dive in, start with a quick pre-test to assess your current level.

You’ll be directed to a quiz on basic grammar and word choice. Please read all instructions carefully before beginning.

💡 Tip: Enter your EditMasters email ID in the quiz form when prompted.

docs.title: 🧩 Quiz Instructions
docs.text:
Avoid extra spaces in your answers. - ❌ (the ) → This will be marked wrong. (Notice the extra space after the word) - ✅ (the) → Correct

Use punctuation marks, not words, for punctuation answers. - ❌ comma - ✅ ,

Complete all questions before submitting the form.

docs.title: 🧪 Choose Your Quiz
docs.text:
Click on the link that best represents your field:

  • HUMANITIES
  • LIFE SCIENCES AND MEDICINE
  • PHYSICAL SCIENCES

Ready? Let’s begin your journey toward mastering editing and proofreading skills with EditMasters. 🚀

docs.title: Sentence Structures
docs.text:
Exercise 1.4.1 (Sentence Structures)

Loading…

docs.title: Substitutes For The Parts Of Speech
🗣️ The Sentence
docs.text:
Overview

Language is thought expressed in words. To express thought, words are combined into sentences. A sentence is a group of words which expresses a complete thought.

docs.title: ✳️ Types of Sentences
docs.text:
• Declarative — asserts something as a fact. • Interrogative — asks a question. • Imperative — expresses a command or request. • Exclamatory — expresses an emotion, such as surprise or grief, in the form of an exclamation or cry.

A declarative, interrogative, or imperative sentence may also be exclamatory.

docs.title: 🔤 Subject and Predicate
docs.text:
Structure of a Sentence

• Every sentence consists of a subject and a predicate.

• The subject of a sentence designates the person, place or thing that the sentence is about; the predicate is that which is said of the subject.

• The simple subject of a sentence is a noun or pronoun. The simple predicate of a sentence is a verb or verb phrase.

• The simple subject is the main noun or pronoun that the sentence is about. When combined with all the other words that explain, modify or complete its meaning, it forms the complete subject.

• The simple predicate is the main verb or verb phrase that asserts something about the subject. When combined with all the other words that explain, modify or complete its meaning, it forms the complete predicate.

• A compound subject or predicate consists of two or more simple subjects or predicates, joined, when necessary, by conjunctions.

• Either the subject or the predicate, or both, may be compound.

docs.title: 🧱 The Parts of Speech
docs.text: In accordance with their use in a sentence, words are divided into eight parts of speech: nouns, pronouns, adjectives, verbs, adverbs, prepositions, conjunctions, and interjections.

docs.title: 1️⃣ Nouns and Pronouns
docs.text:
(1) A noun is the name of a person, place or thing.

(2) A pronoun is a word used instead of a noun. It designates a person, place or thing without naming it.

Nouns and pronouns are called substantives. The substantive to which a pronoun refers is called its antecedent.

docs.title: 2️⃣ Adjectives
docs.text:
(3) An adjective is a word that describes or limits a substantive. This is usually done by indicating a specific quality.

An adjective is said to “belong” to the substantive that it describes or limits.

An adjective that describes is called a descriptive adjective; one that points out or designates is called a definitive adjective.

An article is considered an adjective. ‘A’ or ‘an’ are indefinite articles used to denote a nonspecific substantive. ‘The’ is a definite article used to denote a specific substantive.

docs.title: 3️⃣ Verbs
docs.text:
(4) A verb is a word that asserts something (usually an action) concerning a person, place or thing.

Some verbs express a state or condition rather than an action. A group of words that is used as a verb is called a verb phrase.

Certain verbs, when used to make verb-phrases, are called auxiliary (or aiding) verbs, because they help other verbs to express an action or a state.

Is (in its various forms) and several other verbs may be used to frame sentences in which a word or words in the predicate describe or define the subject. In such sentences, is and other verbs used for the same purpose are called copulative (or linking) verbs.

The infinitive is a verb form that can act as a noun or a modifier and is commonly preceded by the preposition to, which is indicative of the infinitive form.

The participle is a verb form that has no subject and acts like an adjective. It expresses an action or a state in such a way as to describe or limit a substantive.

A participle is said to “belong” to the substantive that it describes or limits.

The two main types of participles are present participles and past participles, based on the time that they denote.

docs.title: 4️⃣ Adverbs
docs.text:
(5) An adverb is a word that modifies a verb, an adjective, or another adverb.

A word or group of words that changes or modifies the meaning of another word is called a modifier. Adjectives and adverbs are both modifiers.

docs.title: 5️⃣ Prepositions, Conjunctions, and Interjections
docs.text:
(6) A preposition is a word placed before a substantive to show its relation to another word in the sentence. The substantive that follows a preposition is called its object.

(7) A conjunction connects words or groups of words.

(8) An interjection is a cry or other exclamatory sound expressing an emotion, such as surprise, anger or pleasure.

docs.title: 🧾 Additional Notes
docs.text: • The meaning of a word in a sentence determines the part of speech to which it belongs. • The same word may sometimes be one part of speech, and sometimes another, particularly with infinitives and participles. • Inflection is a change in the form of a word indicating a difference in its meaning. A word thus changed in form is said to be inflected. • The inflection of a substantive is called its declension; that of an adjective or an adverb its comparison; that of a verb its conjugation.

docs.title: 🧩 Phrases
docs.text:
Definition

A phrase is a group of connected words that does not contain a subject or a predicate.

A phrase is equivalent to a part of speech:

• A phrase used as a noun is called a noun phrase. • A phrase used as a verb is called a verb phrase. • A phrase used as an adjective is called an adjective phrase. • A phrase used as an adverb is called an adverbial phrase.

Adjective or adverbial phrases consisting of a preposition and its object, with or without other words, are called prepositional phrases.

docs.title: 🔗 Clauses
docs.text:
A clause is a group of words that forms part of a sentence and contains a subject and a predicate.

A clause used as a part of speech is called a subordinate clause. All other clauses are called independent clauses.

Clauses of the same order or rank are said to be coordinate clauses.

docs.title: 📘 Types of Sentences
docs.text: • Sentences may be simple, compound, complex, or compound-complex. • A simple sentence has only one subject and one predicate, either or both of which may be compound. • A compound sentence consists of two or more independent coordinate clauses, which may or may not be joined by conjunctions. • A complex sentence consists of two or more clauses, one of which is independent and the rest subordinate. • A compound sentence in which one or more of the coordinate clauses are complex is called a compound-complex sentence.

docs.title: 🧠 Subordinate Clauses
docs.text:
• Subordinate clauses, like phrases, are used as parts of speech. They serve as substitutes for nouns, adjectives, or adverbs. • A subordinate clause that is used as a noun is called a noun (or substantive) clause. • A subordinate clause that modifies a substantive is called an adjective clause. • A subordinate clause that serves as an adverbial modifier is called an adverbial clause.

✅ End of Summary

docs.title: Adjective Gradability
docs.text:
Adjectives describe qualities (characteristics) of nouns. Some qualities can vary in intensity or grade, for example:

rather hot, hot, very hot hot, hotter, the hottest

The adjective hot is gradable.

Other qualities cannot vary in intensity or grade because they are:

  • Extremes (for example: freezing)
  • Absolutes (for example: dead)
  • Classifying (for example: nuclear)

The adjectives freezing, dead and nuclear are non-gradable.

docs.title: 🟢 Gradable Adjectives
docs.text:
A gradable adjective can be used with grading adverbs that vary the adjective's grade or intensity. Look at these examples:

“Gradable adjectives” are also called qualitative adjectives. “Grading adverbs” are also called submodifiers.

A gradable adjective can also have comparative and superlative forms:

  • big → bigger → the biggest
  • hot → hotter → the hottest
  • important → more important → the most important

Example sentences:

My teacher was very happy with my homework. That website is reasonably popular. But this one is more popular. He said that France was a little cold and Denmark was rather cold. But Sweden was the coldest.

docs.title: 🔴 Non-gradable Adjectives
docs.text:
A non-gradable adjective cannot be used with grading adverbs:

It was rather freezing outside. The dog was very dead. He is investing in slightly nuclear energy.

Non-gradable adjectives do not normally have comparative and superlative forms:

freezing → more freezing → the most freezing

dead → deader → the deadest

nuclear → more nuclear → the most nuclear

🧠 Tip: Don't try to learn lists of gradable and non-gradable adjectives! It's better to understand what makes an adjective gradable or non-gradable. This is a matter of logic and common sense. Most native-speakers have never heard of gradable and non-gradable adjectives. They just "feel" that it doesn't make sense to say "fairly excellent" or "very unique". You probably have the same idea in your language.

Often, non-gradable adjectives are used alone:

It was freezing outside. The dog was dead. He is investing in nuclear energy.

docs.title: Non-grading Adverbs
docs.text:
A non-gradable adjective can be used with "non-grading adverbs" (which usually just give the adjective extra impact), for example:

Here are some example sentences containing non-grading adverbs with non-gradable adjectives:

Her exam results were absolutely awful. She will have to take the exam again. Is there anything like it in the world? It must be virtually unique. It starts an essentially chemical reaction.

docs.title: ⚖️ Gradable vs Non-gradable Adjectives
docs.text: Some adjectives have more than one meaning or sense. It’s possible for the same adjective to be gradable in one sense and non-gradable in another.

docs.title: 🔤 Adverbs used with Gradable and Non-gradable Adjectives
docs.text: The adverbs really (very much) and fairly and pretty (both meaning “to a significant degree, but less than very”) can often be used with both gradable and non-gradable adjectives.

docs.title: “Quite” with Gradable and Non-gradable Adjectives
docs.text: The sense of the adverb quite changes according to the gradability of the adjective that we use it with.

docs.title: Non-gradable Adjectives
docs.text:
Although we don't recommend that you learn lists of non-gradable adjectives, here are some for reference. You can decide for yourself whether they are extreme, absolute or classifying.

alive, awful, black, boiling, certain, correct, dead, domestic, enormous, environmental, excellent, freezing, furious, gigantic, huge, immediately, impossible, minuscule, mortal, overjoyed, perfect, pregnant, principal, ridiculous, superb, terrible, terrified, unique, unknown, white, whole

docs.title: Non-grading Adverbs
docs.text:
Again, no need to learn lists. Here are a few examples. There are many more. Remember that you cannot use all non-grading adverbs with all non-gradable adjectives. Some collocate (go together). Some don't.

absolutely, almost, completely, entirely, exclusively, fully, largely, mainly, nearly, perfectly, practically, primarily, utterly, virtually

docs.title: 🔹 What Are Comparative Adverbs?
docs.text:
One of the jobs of an adverb is to modify a verb action, for example:

Joe ran fast.

If we want to compare one verb action with another, we can use a comparative adverb, for example:

Joe ran fast, but Mary came first because she ran faster.

We use comparative adverbs when talking about two actions (not three or more). 👉 Comparison is always between two things.

docs.title: ⚙️ How Do We Make Comparative Adverbs?
docs.text: There are three basic ways to make or form a comparative adverb:

docs.title: 1️⃣ One-syllable adverbs: add -er
docs.text:
If an adverb has only one syllable, we usually just add -er to make it comparative: fast → faster

Examples:

⚠️ Note: Most one-syllable adverbs have the same form as their equivalent adjectives. Don’t let this confuse you! Example:

docs.title: 2️⃣ Two-syllable (or longer) adverbs: use more
docs.text:
When an adverb has two or more syllables (like all -ly adverbs), we make it comparative by adding more in front:

quickly → more quickly

Examples:

We can also use less in place of more to suggest a reduction in the action.

Examples:

docs.title: 3️⃣ Irregular Adverbs
docs.text: A few adverbs have irregular comparative forms, for example:

docs.title: 💬 Comparative Adverbs with Informal Forms
docs.text:
Some adverbs have both a formal (“correct”) form with -ly and an informal form without -ly.

Although native speakers may use the informal forms in speech, they should be avoided in formal writing or exams.

docs.title: 🚫 Adverbs with No Comparative Form
docs.text:
Some adverbs cannot be compared. Examples include:

again, first

daily, yesterday

here, there

now, then

never, sometimes

docs.title: 🧠 How Do We Use Comparative Adverbs?
docs.text:
Now that you know how to form comparative adverbs, let’s see how to use them in sentences.

Notice that we use more to show an increase in the action, and less to show a decrease. Also note that the comparative adverb is often followed by than.

Examples:

  • Trains go fast, but planes go faster.
  • Planes go faster than trains.
  • Trains don’t go faster than planes.
  • Trains go more slowly than planes.
  • Planes go less slowly than trains.
  • Joe won because he played better than Jane.
  • Did cities grow more quickly after the Industrial Revolution?
  • He hit the ball more powerfully than his competitor.
  • As we get older, we remember things less easily.
  • Could you talk a bit more quietly, please?
  • Could you talk a bit less loudly, please?
  • I can’t hear you — please speak louder / more loudly.

docs.title: 🌍 Comparing Groups
docs.text:
Although we use comparative adverbs when talking about two actions, one or both of those actions may represent a group.

The planet Mercury revolves around the sun faster than all the other planets.

Here, we are comparing one action (Mercury’s) to one other group of actions (all the other planets).

✅ Summary: Use -er for short adverbs, more/less for long adverbs, and remember the irregulars (better, worse, farther).

docs.title: 🧩 Exercise
docs.text:
Can you guess the personal pronouns of the first or the third person that may be missing here?

  1. He thought the burglars were ——.
  2. He mistook the burglars for ——.
  3. William is better at his lessons than ——.
  4. It is ——.
  5. These are ——.
  6. Nobody volunteered except Edward and ——.
  7. —— boys have formed a debating club.
  8. Mr. Jones is going to give —— boys a baseball field.
  9. Who is there? ——.
  10. Between you and ——, I am not sorry that he has resigned.
  11. If I were ——, I would study art.
  12. Arthur likes you better than ——.
  13. Behind Ruth and —— came the guest of honor.
  14. Automobiles are not for such as ——.
  15. It was —— that Joseph meant.
  16. —— two are always together.
  17. Richard dislikes everybody, —— most of all.
  18. Each of us should do —— best.
  19. Everybody thinks —— own way is wise.
  20. If anybody has a better plan, now is the time for —— to speak.
  21. It was an old-fashioned picnic, every person furnishing —— share of the provisions.
  22. When anybody is talking, it is bad manners to interrupt ——.

💡 Tip: Try reading each sentence aloud — it can help you “feel” which pronoun fits best.

docs.title: Six Preposition Rules
docs.text: Prepositions form a small but very important word class. We use prepositions very frequently. In fact, the prepositions to, of, in, for, on, with, at, by, from are all in the top 25 words in English. If you can understand and correctly use prepositions, it will greatly improve your fluency. And remember, there are not very many prepositions. There are only 150 prepositions, and we only use about 70 of these commonly. The following rules will help you understand and use prepositions correctly.

docs.title: 1. A preposition must have an object
docs.text:
All prepositions have objects. If a "preposition" does not have an object it is not a preposition—it's probably an adverb. A preposition always has an object. An adverb never has an object.

Look at these example sentences:

  • They are in the kitchen. (preposition in has object the kitchen)
  • Please come in. (adverb in has no object; it qualifies come)
  • There was a doorway before me. (preposition before has object me)
  • I had never seen it before. (adverb before has no object; it qualifies seen)
  • I will call after work. (preposition after has object work)
  • He called soon after. (adverb after has no object; it qualifies called)

docs.title: 2. pre-position means place before
docs.text:
The name “preposition” indicates that a preposition (usually) comes before something (its object):

I put it in the box.

But even when a preposition does not come before its object, it is still closely related to its object:

Who did you talk to? / I talked to Jane.

docs.title: 3. A pronoun following a preposition should be in object form
docs.text:
The noun or pronoun that follows a preposition forms a prepositional object. If it is a pronoun, it should therefore be in the objective form (me, her, them), not subjective form (I, she, they):

  • This is from my wife and me.
  • That’s between him and her.
  • Mary gave it to them.

docs.title: 4. Preposition forms
docs.text:
Prepositions have no particular form. The majority of prepositions are one-word prepositions, but some are two- or three-word phrases known as complex prepositions:

  • one-word prepositions: before, into, on
  • complex prepositions: according to, but for, in spite of, on account of

docs.title: 5. to preposition and to infinitive are not the same
docs.text: Do not confuse the infinitive particle “to” (to sing, to live) with the preposition “to” (to London, to me).

docs.title: to as preposition
docs.text:
• I look forward to lunch
  • I look forward to seeing you
  • I look forward to see you
  • They are committed to the project.
  • They are committed to keeping the price down.
  • They are committed to keep the price down.
  • I am used to cars.
  • I am used to driving.
  • I am used to drive.

docs.title: to as infinitive particle
docs.text:
• They used to live in Moscow.
  • They love to sing.

docs.title: 6. The golden preposition rule
docs.text: A preposition is followed by a "noun". It is NEVER followed by a verb.

docs.title: Source
docs.text:
• GrammarBook.com – Problem Prepositions
  • EnglishClub – Preposition Rules

docs.title: Prepositions of Time: at, in, on
docs.text:
We use:

  • at for a PRECISE TIME
  • in for MONTHS, YEARS, CENTURIES and LONG PERIODS
  • on for DAYS and DATES

docs.title: Look at these examples:
docs.text:
• I have a meeting at 9am.
  • The shop closes at midnight.
  • Jane went home at lunchtime.
  • In England, it often snows in December.
  • Do you think we will go to Jupiter in the future?
  • There should be a lot of progress in the next century.
  • Do you work on Mondays?
  • Her birthday is on 20 November.
  • Where will you be on New Year's Day?

docs.title: Notice the use of the preposition of time at in the following standard expressions:
docs.text: Note that in some varieties of English people say "on the weekend" and "on Christmas".

docs.title: Notice the use of the prepositions of time in and on in these common expressions:
docs.text:
When we say last, next, every, this we do not also use at, in, on.

  • I went to London last June. (not in last June)
  • He's coming back next Tuesday. (not on next Tuesday)
  • I go home every Easter. (not at every Easter)
  • We'll call you this evening. (not in this evening)

docs.title: Source
docs.text: https://www.englishclub.com/grammar/prepositions-at-in-on-time.htm
